title: Any self-taught quantum physicists out there? What subjects, and in which order do you consider prerequisite to pursuing particle physics? For someone with no formal education? - Quora

response.answer_text: “No Formal Education”?? In Mathematics, does that mean NO (1) Basic Algebra, (2) Advanced Algebra, (3) Trigonometry, (4) Probability and Statistics, (5) Calculus, (6) Advanced Calculus including domains of convergence, (7) Linear Algebra, (8) Differential Equations, (9) Multivariate Calculus, (10) Vector and Tensor Calculus, (11) Complex Analysis, (12) Higher Transcendental Functions such as Bessel Functions and Hankel Functions, (13) Jacobians of Transformation, (14) Dirac Delta-Functions, and (15) Hilbert Spaces? In Physics, does it mean NO (A) Classical Mechanics, (B) Conservation of Energy and Conservation of Momentum, (C) Open and Closed Systems, (D) Constraints and Constraint Equations, (E) Lagrangians and Hamiltonians, (F) Special and General Relativity, (G) Maxwell’s Equations, (H) Thermodynamics, (I) Atomic and Molecular Physics, (J) Basic Quantum Mechanics including the Hydrogen Atom, (I) Schrodinger and Heisenberg Representations (J) Statistical Thermodynamics, (K) Classical Electrostatics and Electrodynamics, (L) Laplace’s and Poisson’s Equations, (M) Spectroscopy, (N) Astrophysics and the Balmer’s Series, (O) Nuclear Physics including Fusion and Fission, (P) Plasmas, (Q) Solid State Physics including crystals and conductivity, (R) Molecular Physics of Crystals and Gases including Symmetry Groups for solids, (S) Quantum Electrodynamics, and finally (T) Quantum Field Theory? Assuming you have access to a very good library, maybe you could learn all of the above (1)-(15) in Math, and (A)-(T) in Physics, on your own, but you’d probably be better off by taking some college-level and graduate-level classes to help you succeed. Have you learned some of this stuff on your own already? Here is a little test for you. Can you answer these 4 easy questions in 100 words or less without equations, and can you answer the 5th question in 100 pages or less with equations? [i] Why is Special Relativity excluded from “Classical Mechanics” but is required for “Classical Electrodynamics”? [ii] Why is Water (H2O) a polar molecule, but Carbon Dioxide (CO2) is non-polar? [ iii] For Earth, why is no Element #43 found, very little Element #2, and oodles of Element #26? [iv] What Physics is involved in the creation and use of your Cell Phone? [v] Can you derive the Electromagnetic Tensor from first principles? Finally, it is one thing to have a good understanding of these topics, so that you can pick up specialized technical Journal dedicated to a sub-field, and read and understand the papers. It is another thing altogether to do Research in those fields. Has anyone every done anything like this? I know of one case. At age 16, he was a freshman in Columbia University, and was failing English. He went to the Head of the Physics Department, who at that time was Nobel Laureate Isidor Isaac Rabi. The kid was literally crying his eyes out (boo-hoo-hoo!), saying he loves physics SOOO MUCH and may never get to be a Physicist because of Freshman English. Prof. Rabi was ignoring the sobbing freshman because he was busy discussing some finer points of the latest Phys. Rev. paper in Quantum Electrodynamics with another Professor. The sobbing freshman’s tears all dried up, and he started intensely following the discussion, as this was his favorite topic. He then started offering some suggestions to help fix some of the things they were worried about. Prof. Rabi was initially dismissive, basically saying, “We are Professors who are discussing items at the cutting edge of Theoretical Physics Research. This is from the latest Phys. Rev. paper just published. You don’t have a clue what we are talking about.” The 16-year old said, “NO! This is my favorite topic. I get Phys. Rev. at home, and I was thinking about these exact same questions!” Prof. Rabi said, “OK, what field are we talking about?” The 16-year old said without hesitation, “Quantum Electrodynamics!” Prof. Rabi was duly surprised, and then said, “So, why are you in my office anyway?” Back to the “boo-hoo-hoo” and sobs and tears. Prof. Rabi said, “OK. Let me get your name. I will personally ensure that you do not fail freshman English.” “Really??” Big smiles. Then the kid realized, “Oh, no! I should have been talking to the Head of the English Department! You really can’t help me, because that’s a different department.” Prof. Rabi then said, “I already told you that I will personally ensure that you do not fail English, so don’t worry about it!” I guess a Nobel Prize in Physics has more clout than just a simple Department Head in English (who did not have a Nobel Prize). The kid did not fail Freshman English. His name was Julian Schwinger. He eventually got his own Nobel Prize in Physics.

“To learn QM” means to learn the mathematical theory as described in a textbook.It does not mean to learn some vague concepts about superposition and duality, as presented in pop-science books (and sadly in many bad “spiritual” books).If you are asking about 1., then you need to first study, at an introductory level, linear algebra, calculus and differential equations. If you are asking about 2., then there are a few half-way decent books by real scientists — make sure that this is the case. Gribbin may be among the most clear. Perhaps Paul Davis.

Let’s get real here. Self-taught quantum physicists (as in actual research level, publishing in refereed journals) as about as common as self taught neuro-surgeons. You wouldn’t want to deal with either one. Find another field.

I suggest starting with ordinary quantum mechanics and tackle particle physics later. Nothing special, just solid foundations. Especially get rid of all classical pictures. I can recommend the Feynman Lectures. They do not neglect the experimental difficulties and tell quite well what is really done.
